content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a hard time lately. My wife pushed me to come here, but honestly, I’m not sure if this is going to help. Things at home with my son and my marriage are really overwhelming, and I’m just feeling lost.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like things have been feeling heavy for you lately, with both family and personal struggles weighing on you. It’s understandable to feel unsure about where to start, but it’s great that you’re here, even if it was your wife who encouraged it. What’s been the most challenging for you recently?

It feels like everything is piling up at once. My son’s behavior has been really hard to deal with, and my wife and I don’t know what we’re doing wrong or how to help him, and it’s causing a lot of tension between us. It feels like I’m failing as a dad and a husband, and I just can’t concentrate on work or enjoy anything right now. I don’t even know where to start.

That sounds like a lot to carry all at once—feeling like things are overwhelming with your son, navigating the strain in your marriage, and then trying to keep it together at work on top of it all. It’s understandable that you might feel stuck or unsure of where to begin. It sounds like you’re really concerned about being a good dad and a good partner. What do you think gets in the way of finding some relief or a way forward right now?

Honestly, I think it’s just this constant feeling of not knowing what to do. Every time we try something new with my son, it either doesn’t seem to work, or it causes more arguments between me and my wife. It feels like no matter what I try, I’m letting everyone down. It’s hard to even think straight to figure out where to start when things feel this chaotic.

It sounds like the uncertainty and repeated efforts that don't lead to the results you hoped for are leaving you feeling stuck and defeated. You’re trying really hard to find solutions and balance everything, but the frustration of not seeing things improve seems to weigh heavily and create even more tension. It’s clear you care deeply about your family and want to make things better, even if it feels messy right now. What’s been helping you keep going despite feeling this way?

Honestly, I don’t know. I guess it’s just the fact that I want to be there for my family, even if I feel like I’m not doing enough. I can’t imagine giving up on them, even though it feels like I’m at my breaking point. I just don’t want to lose everything.

Your commitment to your family, even through all this difficulty, says so much about your strength and how much you care. It’s clear how important being there for your wife and son is to you, even when it feels overwhelming or you’re questioning yourself. Holding on to that desire to keep trying, even at a breaking point, shows how deeply you value them. What do you think would help you start to feel a little more steady or hopeful as you go through this?

I’m not really sure what would help, to be honest. It feels like there’s so much to fix that I don’t even know where to start. Maybe if my wife and I could figure out how to work together more, or if we could find some real way to help my son, things might start to feel a little less impossible. But right now, it just feels like it’s all too much.

It sounds like finding a way to work more as a team with your wife and figuring out how to support your son are really important to you and could ease some of the weight you’re feeling. At the same time, it’s tough to imagine how to begin when everything feels overwhelming. That sense of being stuck can make it hard to see a way forward, but the fact that you’re thinking about what might help shows there’s still hope in all of this. What do you think is one small step, even if it feels uncertain, that you and your wife could take together right now?

I don’t know… I guess maybe we could talk more without turning it into an argument. But it feels like we’re always so tense or exhausted that conversations just spiral. I’d want to figure out how to do that, but I honestly have no idea where to start or if it would even help in the long run. It’s frustrating.

It’s really hard to feel like even small conversations turn into bigger conflicts, especially when both of you are running on empty. Wanting to communicate better is such a meaningful step, though—it shows how much you value your relationship and want to find solutions together. While it sounds frustrating not to know where or how to start, it’s clear that your intention is to build more understanding and connection. What might it feel like to talk with your wife about your shared hopes for your family, even if it’s just to acknowledge what you’re both going through right now?

It might help to just tell her how overwhelmed I am and how much I want us to figure things out together. Maybe starting with just listening to each other without trying to fix everything in the moment could make it less tense. It’s scary to bring it up because I don’t want to make things worse, but I know I can’t keep avoiding it either.

It sounds like being open and sharing how you’re feeling, along with creating space for both of you to listen to each other, could be a meaningful place to begin. Even though it’s scary to bring it up, it shows real courage and care that you’re willing to take that step for the sake of your relationship. You’re trying to create a moment of connection rather than fix everything all at once, which could help lower the tension and start rebuilding that communication. How can you prepare yourself to approach that conversation in a way that feels manageable for both of you?

Maybe I could pick a time when things are calmer, like after the kids are in bed, and just let her know how I’ve been feeling without blaming myself or her. I’d want to keep it simple and focus on how much I want us to work through this together. I guess I’d have to remind myself to just take it one step at a time and not expect everything to change overnight. It still feels a little overwhelming, but I think I can try.

That sounds like a thoughtful and caring approach—choosing a calmer moment, sharing your feelings without blame, and expressing the hope to work through things as a team. Focusing on just one honest and supportive conversation at a time feels like a manageable way to start, and it’s admirable that you’re thinking about how to create the right space for both of you. Taking it step by step makes such a big difference, and even small efforts like this can help set a new tone. How do you feel about giving this a try? And is there anything else on your mind that you’d like to talk through?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
